docs.abstract: Apple’s new smartphones start at $999 and $1,099, but their superb cameras and screens make them worth the high prices, our reviewer writes.
docs.snippet: Apple’s new smartphones start at $999 and $1,099, but their superb cameras and screens make them worth the high prices, our reviewer writes.
docs.lead_paragraph: For the past few years, I have been a naysayer on one feature of smartphones: their growing size.

headline.main: The iPhone XS and XS Max Review: Big Screens That Are a Delight to Use

docs.abstract: The heart monitor should not be considered a medical device and reflects wider problems with health screens.
docs.snippet: The heart monitor should not be considered a medical device and reflects wider problems with health screens.
docs.lead_paragraph: The newest version of the Apple Watch will feature a heart monitor app that can do a form of an electrocardiogram. Many have greeted this announcement as a great leap forward for health. The president of the American Heart Association even took part in the product launch.

headline.main: That New Apple Watch EKG Feature? There Are More Downs Than Ups

docs.abstract: Here’s a reminder of how technology aspirations and competition are at the heart of the battle between the United States and China.
docs.snippet: Here’s a reminder of how technology aspirations and competition are at the heart of the battle between the United States and China.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: What Trump’s Trade War Is Really About

docs.abstract: An app that really fosters intimacy — but only with those you know best.
docs.snippet: An app that really fosters intimacy — but only with those you know best.
docs.lead_paragraph: Lurking on my phone is an app I didn’t put there, one I wouldn’t have touched were it not for a few glasses of wine and a pointer-fingered dare from an insolent friend named Jeff. He was visiting from San Francisco, and as we sat in the white-brick backyard of a bar, he urged me to disclose my location to him on Find My Friends, a function that Apple began quietly placing on all iPhones in 2015. In a world where we use social media to broadcast highly curated versions of ourselves, the app offers a frightening antithesis: to tell the people in our lives, via a small orange dot moving across a map, exactly where we are at all times. “What are you hiding?” Jeff asked me, giggling and snapping his gum like some teenage villain.

headline.main: Letter of Recommendation: Find My Friends

docs.abstract: It has been a long time coming, but Apple could soon be worth $1 trillion — and counting.
docs.snippet: It has been a long time coming, but Apple could soon be worth $1 trillion — and counting.
docs.lead_paragraph: It has been a long time coming, but Apple could soon be worth $1 trillion — and counting. At about $940 billion, the tech giant is close to being the first company to pass that threshold in market capitalization, as Breakingviews predicted seven years ago. Growth has slowed since then, but customers remain loyal and today’s valuation is far from stretched. Apple’s timely focus on data privacy may help it get there.

headline.main: Apple’s Market Value Should Cross $1 Trillion and Keep On Trucking

docs.abstract: The company’s $550 million investment is another sign of how American tech giants still want to do business in China, despite the many hurdles.
docs.snippet: The company’s $550 million investment is another sign of how American tech giants still want to do business in China, despite the many hurdles.

headline.main: Google’s JD.com Deal Shows Silicon Valley Still Wants In on China
headline.print_headline: Barriers to Doing Business In China Haven’t Reduced Interest From Tech Giants

docs.abstract: European authorities are testing the idea that data can give companies an unfair edge over rivals.
docs.snippet: European authorities are testing the idea that data can give companies an unfair edge over rivals.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — If data is the most valuable currency of the digital economy, at what point does a company have so much that it becomes unfair?

headline.main: Apple’s Deal for Shazam Is Delayed in Europe Over Data Concerns
headline.print_headline: Apple Deal Faces Review Over the Data It Brings In

docs.abstract: Reporting on secretive technology companies sometimes means finding people who don’t want to be found. Jack Nicas, who covers Apple, relies on some old-school methods.
docs.snippet: Reporting on secretive technology companies sometimes means finding people who don’t want to be found. Jack Nicas, who covers Apple, relies on some old-school methods.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Jack Nicas, a technology reporter for The Times in San Francisco, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline.main: The Essentials for Covering Silicon Valley: Burner Phones and Doorbells
headline.print_headline: Covering Silicon Valley With Burner Phones and Doorbells

docs.abstract: Apple showed new smartphones — including its biggest ever — for higher prices, and upgraded its smart watches so they become more of a health device.
docs.snippet: Apple showed new smartphones — including its biggest ever — for higher prices, and upgraded its smart watches so they become more of a health device.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple has long had a playbook for iPhones, its most important product: Keep rolling out bigger, faster and more expensive models.

headline.main: Apple Unveils Bigger iPhones at Higher Prices, and a Heart-Tracking Watch
headline.print_headline: Apple Unveils Bigger iPhones at Heftier Prices

byline.original: By Brian X. Chen, Jack Nicas, Farhad Manjoo and Reed Abelson

docs.abstract: The U.S. and China are threatening a global trade war as they look to protect their most advanced industries.
docs.snippet: The U.S. and China are threatening a global trade war as they look to protect their most advanced industries.
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States undercut China’s technology ambitions on Tuesday, advancing a new rule that would limit the ability of Chinese telecommunications companies to sell their products in this country.

headline.main: Huawei and ZTE Hit Hard as U.S. Moves Against Chinese Tech Firms
headline.print_headline: U.S. Limiting Chinese Sales In Tech Battle

byline.original: By Raymond Zhong, Paul Mozur and Jack Nicas
